title: Beyond Practicality
devotional:
Eliza had always considered herself a practical woman. Faith was fine, she thought, but obedience? That seemed a bit…blind. She preferred to see the logic in things, to understand the "why" before committing to the "what." This approach served her well in her career as an engineer, where precision and rationale were paramount. One day, however, Eliza found herself at a crossroads. Her company was bidding on a lucrative government contract, one that would secure their future for years to come. But the details of the project were troubling. There were whispers of cutting corners, of using substandard materials to maximize profit. Eliza knew this was wrong, morally and ethically. She voiced her concerns to her superiors, but they dismissed them, reminding her of the potential financial windfall. "Just do your job, Eliza," her boss said. "Don't ask questions." Eliza was torn. On one hand, there was the promise of security and advancement, the validation of her hard work. On the other, there was her conscience, the quiet voice within urging her to stand for what was right, even if it meant jeopardizing her career. She spent sleepless nights wrestling with her decision. Was it truly her responsibility to challenge the status quo? Could she trust that God would provide if she chose the path of obedience, even if it seemed foolish in the eyes of the world?

In those dark hours, Eliza turned to scripture, seeking guidance. She stumbled upon the story of Noah, building an ark in the middle of a dry land, a seemingly absurd act of obedience to a God he couldn't see. And yet, Noah's obedience saved him and his family from the coming flood. Eliza realized that obedience wasn't about blind faith, but about trusting in a wisdom greater than her own. It was about aligning her will with God's, even when she couldn't fully understand His plan. With newfound clarity, Eliza made her decision. She refused to compromise her integrity. She gathered evidence of the unethical practices and presented it to the appropriate authorities. The consequences were swift and severe. She lost her job, faced ridicule from her colleagues, and endured a period of financial hardship. But amidst the storm, Eliza felt a deep sense of peace. She knew she had done the right thing, that she had honored God with her obedience. And as she trusted that God would provide, unexpected opportunities began to emerge, opportunities that aligned with her values and allowed her to use her talents for good.
image_description: A partially open wooden door revealing a bright path with a sign pointing in two directions.
insights: Eliza's story mirrors the challenges faced by many believers who are called to prioritize obedience over worldly gain. Deuteronomy 28:1-2 promises blessings for obedience: "If you fully obey the Lord your God and carefully follow all his commands I give you today, the Lord your God will set you high above all the nations on earth. All these blessings will come on you and accompany you if you obey the Lord your God." However, obedience doesn't always guarantee immediate or tangible rewards. Often, it requires sacrifice and faith, trusting that God's ultimate plan is greater than our immediate understanding. As Jesus demonstrated in the Garden of Gethsemane, true obedience involves surrendering our will to God's, even when it leads to suffering (Matthew 26:39).
prayer: Heavenly Father, I confess that obedience is not always easy. I often struggle to surrender my will to Yours, especially when it requires sacrifice or discomfort. Help me to trust in Your wisdom and to align my actions with Your commands, even when I don't fully understand Your plan. Grant me the courage to stand for what is right, even when it's unpopular or challenging. Fill me with Your peace and assurance, knowing that You will never abandon me. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: In what areas of your life are you struggling to obey God's will? What fears or anxieties are holding you back from fully surrendering to His plan? How can you actively cultivate a spirit of obedience, trusting that God's wisdom is greater than your own?
